Today, a Watt installed costs about $2 and makes about 20 cents of electricity per year.  That’s a 10%/year return & tax free.  But offgrid is more costly since battery depreciation costs about 10 to 40 cents per kWHr. The battery produces no electricity and therefore no return.

Had Khaki Campbell 🦆.  Switched to meat/dual purpose ducks because egg layers aren’t big enough to eat and the meat birds lay plenty of eggs. For breeding stock: we have 1 Pekin, 2 Blue Swedes, 2 Cayuga ducks plus a Pekin drake. I like the Pekin-Cayuga cross offspring.

biggest time savings, kill the TV.  The other key, an understanding spouse and long time frames (reasonable expectations). We have been working on our house for over a decade because we try to do so much ourselves.

do’s: 

solar is better than wind or hydro.

whatever battery you get, study everything about it and baby it.

don’t’s:

Don’t plan to heat much with you off grid electricity.  You’ll need wood or gas if you live north of say GA/SC.

Don’t tick off or ignore your neighbors.
It would take a really special location to make hydro feasible or competitive with solar. I’d love to hydro and wind but it just doesn’t pencil out here.

all of our own beef, eggs, peaches, pears, apples, & chickens/ducks for eating. (We have 4 deep freezers) So 75% of our protein and 50% of our fruit. (20% overall?) Used to can our veggies but no time for a big garden now. We have 50,000 pounds of cattle on the hoof that we sell.

Dug well (actually a spring), runs through calcium carbonate (to change ph, ours is naturally acidic), and a non consumable media that filters ferric iron. No UV, but run the drinking tap & ice maker water thru a reverse osmosis system from Lowe’s. Every situation is diff tho.
If there’s a battery break-thru (eg, 50% cost reduction), living off the grid becomes cost competitive in many scenarios. Battery storage is the major hurdle for off grid today.

*build the smallest housing unit you can finish & plan to expand later. Or get a lightly used mobile home like we did.

*focus on energy saving, not production. On the electricity production, go modular & expand.

*if you do get equipment, a used backhoe is better than a tractor.
